multiple-choice.question: What can be done to prevent or delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Only a cure can prevent or delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: B
options.text: A healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and sufficient sleep, can help prevent or delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Only medication can prevent or delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no way to prevent or delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is cognitive reserve, and how can it help protect against Alzheimer's disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive reserve is the ability to remember and recall information, and it can help protect against Alzheimer's disease by reducing the risk of memory loss.

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive reserve is the ability to adapt and compensate for cognitive decline, and it can help protect against Alzheimer's disease by allowing the brain to continue functioning despite the presence of disease pathology.

options.label: C
options.text: Cognitive reserve is the ability to learn and remember new information, and it can help protect against Alzheimer's disease by reducing the risk of cognitive decline.

options.label: D
options.text: Cognitive reserve is the ability to forget and ignore information, and it can help protect against Alzheimer's disease by reducing the risk of memory loss.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Nun Study in understanding Alzheimer's disease?

options.label: A
options.text: The Nun Study shows that a high level of cognitive reserve can reduce the risk of Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: B
options.text: The Nun Study shows that a low level of cognitive reserve can increase the risk of Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: C
options.text: The Nun Study shows that a high level of education can reduce the risk of Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: D
options.text: The Nun Study shows that a low level of education can increase the risk of Alzheimer's disease.

multiple-choice.question: What can be done to build an Alzheimer's-resistant brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Engaging in mentally stimulating activities, such as reading and learning new skills, can help build an Alzheimer's-resistant brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Only medication can build an Alzheimer's-resistant brain.

options.label: C
options.text: A healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and regular exercise, can help build an Alzheimer's-resistant brain.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no way to build an Alzheimer's-resistant brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between sleep and Alzheimer's disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Sleep has no relationship with Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Sleep can help prevent or delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Sleep can increase the risk of Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Sleep has a complex relationship with Alzheimer's disease, and more research is needed to understand it.

multiple-choice.question: What can be learned from people living with Alzheimer's disease?

options.label: A
options.text: People living with Alzheimer's disease are unable to learn or remember anything.

options.label: B
options.text: People living with Alzheimer's disease can learn and remember new information, but only in the early stages of the disease.

options.label: C
options.text: People living with Alzheimer's disease can learn and remember new information, and can even adapt and compensate for cognitive decline.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no way to learn from people living with Alzheimer's disease.

title: Secrets of the X chromosome - Robin Ball

multiple-choice.question: How many pairs of chromosomes do humans have in their cells?

title: Why do we itch? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why we itch when we have a bug bite?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our skin is allergic to the anticoagulant released by the mosquito.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the anticoagulant triggers the release of histamine, which makes our capillaries swell.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the mosquito's bite causes a chemical reaction that stimulates our nerve endings.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the bug bite causes a physical irritation that stimulates our skin.

options.label: A

options.text: It is a molecule that triggers a signal that is carried up the spinal cord to the brain, where it creates the feeling of an itch.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a molecule that stimulates the release of histamine, which makes our capillaries swell.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a molecule that has no role in the sensation of itching.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: So that we can communicate with other people through touch.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: By using physical therapy to strengthen the remaining muscles.
